title: Cup day fun goes off-track
text:
2015 Geelong Cup fashion tips and tricks from expert Renee Enright by: What are these? Jessica Paulke and Laura Sheppard model this season’s spring racing trends. Picture: Mitch Bear Source: News Corp Australia 
It’s time to colour co-ordinate your fascinator-dress-shoes combo — there are only a few days left until the Geelong Cup is upon us. 
Wednesday’s event at the Breakwater racecourse will have plenty on offer to go along with the on-track entertainment. 
Victorian Miss Universe Australia finalist Alex Hecker will be hosting the gt Fashions on the Field competition, giving out more than $25,000 in prizes, while a roving jazz band and live musicians will serenade racegoers as they set up picnic rugs on the rolling green hillsides. Squire Shoppe owner Hayden Spurling in his Geelong Cup shop window. Source: News Corp Australia 
There are also tickets still available for the selection of lounges and marquees, each with a different tone to keep punters happy — from the pamper area and burger bar of the Sporting Globe marquee, to the Tobin Bronze tent replete with door prizes, waiters, and a three-course gourmet luncheon. 
They’ll be supported throughout the public holiday by a legion of food vendors and bar staff. 
Geelong Racing Club CEO Daniel Salter said he was “looking forward” to another huge event, which is expected to attract more than 20,000 people. 
“We really hope for a bumper turnout here on the day,” Mr Salter said. 
The Geelong Racing Club celebrate its 150th anniversary this year, but the CEO said all of Wednesday’s focus will be on the high-stakes Geelong Cup. 
The first Geelong Cup was held over a two-mile track in 1872, before the racecourse was transferred to its present Breakwater Rd site in 1903. 
Since then, the Geelong event has become the main pathway through to the prestigious Melbourne Cup: “the race that stops a nation”. 
Buses are available to book to ferry racegoers from Barwon Heads and Torquay. 
The official race day afterparty kicks off back at The Sporting Globe from 5.30pm on Wednesday. Renee’s Cup Day fashion tips 
Westfield stylist and gt columnist Renee Enright lists her top tips for Cup Day fashion. 
— My one tip each and every year come spring racing season is to keep it classy. 
— Colour is such a huge trend this season so expect to see plenty of bold hues and vibrant prints. 
— Classic monochrome is always on point and I expect to see plenty of white-on-white fresh spring looks. 
— With lace also being such a standout trend for spring/summer, I think we will definitely see this feature heavily trackside. 
— Off the shoulder detail dresses and tops will also be quite popular, as will crowns and delicate headwear. 
— Ensure you have an option for wet/cold weather, like a structured blazer or jacket. 
— Comfortable shoes are key, so think wedges or thick-set heels. 
— For the gents, navy is going to be a nice alternative to black suits. 
— Guys, ensure you have a well fitted suit and step outside the box a little. 
— And have fun with your accessories — pocket squares, fun printed ties or headwear can be the little finishing touch your outfit needs.
